definitions: narrow opening or crack in rock, earth, or other solid material
abnormal tear or opening in body tissue or organ
examples: The earthquake created deep fissures in the canyon walls
Water seeped through the fissures in the basement foundation
The surgeon repaired the anal fissure during the procedure
Chronic fissures can cause significant pain and bleeding

definitions: hand with fingers bent inward and pressed tightly against the palm
examples: He pounded his fist on the table in anger
The boxer raised her fists in victory celebration
She made a fist to test her grip strength
The baby's tiny fists were clenched while sleeping

definitions: physical fight between people using their fists as weapons
examples: The argument escalated into a fistfight outside the bar
Security broke up the fistfight between the two students
He got into a fistfight defending his brother's honor
The movie featured an intense fistfight scene

definitions: amount that can be held in a closed fist
examples: She grabbed a fistful of candy from the bowl
He pulled out a fistful of dollars from his pocket
The child picked a fistful of wildflowers for her mother
Add a fistful of pasta to the boiling water

definitions: abnormal passageway between two organs or vessels that normally do not connect
examples: The patient developed a fistula between the bowel and bladder
Surgical intervention was required to close the arteriovenous fistula
Obstetric fistulas can occur after prolonged childbirth complications
The doctor diagnosed a fistula causing chronic infection

definitions: state of physical health and strength from exercise
sudden attack or convulsion, especially of illness or emotion
way clothing conforms to body shape and size
examples: Regular exercise keeps you in good physical fit
His cardiovascular fit improved after months of training
The child threw a fit when denied candy
She suffered an epileptic fit during the presentation
The tailor ensured a perfect fit for the suit
These shoes have a comfortable fit for wide feet

definitions: skilled worker who assembles or installs machinery, equipment, or pipes
person who is physically fit or becoming fitter
examples: The pipe fitter installed new plumbing throughout the building
She works as a fitter at the aircraft assembly plant
Marathon runners are typically much fitter than average people
He's fitter now than he was in college

definitions: small part used to join or attach pipes, tubes, or other components
session for adjusting or trying on clothing items
quality of being suitable or appropriate for circumstances
examples: The plumber replaced the corroded pipe fitting
Buy extra fittings when installing the new bathroom fixtures
She scheduled a fitting for her wedding dress alterations
The tailor requires three fittings for custom suits
It was a fitting tribute to the war veterans
The punishment was a fitting response to the crime

definitions: cardinal number between four and six
banknote worth five units of currency
group or set containing five members or items
examples: The recipe calls for five eggs and two cups of flour
She has five children ranging from toddlers to teenagers
Can you break this twenty into four fives please
He slipped a five into the tip jar
The basketball team starts with its best five players
They formed a five to perform jazz standards

definitions: repair or correction that solves a problem
difficult or awkward situation requiring resolution
dose of addictive drug taken by dependent person
examples: The software fix resolved the security vulnerability
We need a permanent fix for the leaking roof
She found herself in a fix with conflicting commitments
How did we get into this fix with the deadline
The addict desperately sought his next fix
Withdrawal begins hours after the last fix

definitions: unhealthy or obsessive preoccupation with particular person, object, or idea
process of making something firm, stable, or permanently attached
examples: His fixation on perfection prevented him from finishing projects
She developed an unhealthy fixation on her appearance
The surgeon used pins for bone fixation after the fracture
Nitrogen fixation converts atmospheric nitrogen into usable compounds

definitions: person who arranges or repairs things, often through unofficial means
chemical solution used to make photographic images permanent
examples: The political fixer arranged meetings with influential donors
She hired a fixer to navigate the foreign bureaucracy
Apply fixer to the photograph after developing
The darkroom ran out of fixer solution

definitions: act or process of repairing or securing something
side dishes and condiments served with main course
examples: The roof fixing took longer than expected
Fixing the engine required specialized tools
Turkey with all the fixings makes a traditional holiday meal
The burger came with fixings on the side

definitions: item of furniture or equipment fixed in position in building
scheduled sports match or competitive event
person or thing that has been somewhere so long they seem permanent
examples: The bathroom fixtures include a new sink and toilet
Light fixtures throughout the house need updating
The derby is an important fixture in the soccer calendar
Today's fixture pits the champions against the underdogs
He's been a fixture at the local bar for twenty years
The old clock tower is a fixture in the town square

definitions: bubbling or hissing sound and appearance from gas escaping liquid
carbonated soft drink or sparkling beverage
examples: The fizz from the champagne tickled her nose
You can hear the fizz when opening a soda can
She ordered a gin fizz at the cocktail bar
The kids enjoyed fruit fizz at the party

definitions: narrow inlet of sea between high cliffs formed by glacial erosion
examples: Norway's fjords attract millions of tourists each year
The cruise ship sailed through the spectacular fjord
Milford Sound is New Zealand's most famous fjord
Glaciers carved these deep fjords over millennia

definitions: press agent or publicist who promotes clients
heavy criticism or hostile reaction
examples: The celebrity's flack issued a statement denying the rumors
She worked as a flack for several Hollywood studios
The company caught flack for its environmental policies
He's taking flack from critics over his latest decision

definitions: piece of cloth with distinctive design representing country or organization
marker or indicator used for signaling or identification
flat rectangular stone used for paving
examples: The flag flew at half-mast to honor fallen soldiers
Each country's flag was displayed at the Olympics
Red flags marked the dangerous areas on the ski slope
The referee threw a penalty flag on the play
The patio was paved with sandstone flags
Old flags lined the garden pathway

definitions: act of whipping or flogging as punishment or torture
religious or psychological practice of self-inflicted whipping for penance
examples: Historical accounts describe flagellation as common judicial punishment
The prisoner endured flagellation before his execution
Medieval monks practiced flagellation as religious penance
Some cults encourage flagellation for spiritual purification

definitions: gradual decrease in strength, vigor, or enthusiasm
flat stones collectively used for paving walkways or floors
examples: His flagging energy showed in the final marathon miles
Sales showed flagging momentum in the fourth quarter
The old flagging in the courtyard needs replacement
Stone flagging creates an attractive garden path

definitions: tall pole or staff from which flag is displayed
examples: The school flagpole stands thirty feet tall
They raised the flag on the flagpole every morning
Lightning struck the metal flagpole during the storm
Students gathered around the flagpole for the ceremony

definitions: ship carrying commanding admiral and flying distinguishing flag
most important or successful product, location, or entity of organization
examples: The admiral commanded the fleet from his flagship
The flagship led the naval formation into battle
This store is the company's flagship location
Their flagship product generates most of their revenue

definitions: pole or staff on which flag is raised and displayed
examples: The flagstaff bent under the strong winds
They installed a new flagstaff in the town square
The ship's flagstaff displayed the national colors
Veterans saluted as the flag rose up the flagstaff

definitions: flat stone slab used for paving paths, patios, or floors
examples: Flagstone pathways wound through the garden
They chose natural flagstone for the patio surface
The old flagstone floor showed centuries of wear
Moss grew between the flagstone pavers

definitions: agricultural tool with hinged stick for threshing grain
uncontrolled swinging or thrashing movement of limbs
examples: Farmers used flails to separate grain from stalks
The medieval flail hung in the barn museum
His arms flailed wildly as he lost his balance
The drowning swimmer's flail attracted the lifeguard's attention

definitions: natural ability or aptitude for something
distinctive elegance or style in appearance or behavior
examples: She has a flair for languages and speaks five fluently
His flair for comedy made him popular at parties
The designer decorated the room with artistic flair
She dressed with flair that turned heads everywhere

definitions: antiaircraft artillery fire or exploding shells
strong criticism or hostile reaction
examples: The bomber encountered heavy flak over enemy territory
Flak burst around the aircraft during the raid
The politician caught flak for his controversial statement
She's taking flak from environmentalists over the decision

definitions: small flat thin piece that breaks away from larger whole
person who is unreliable or acts strangely
form of cocaine prepared for smoking
examples: Snow flakes drifted down from the gray sky
Paint flakes peeled off the old wooden fence
Don't count on him showing up, he's such a flake
That flake forgot our meeting three times
Police found flakes of crack in his pocket
The dealer sold flakes to undercover officers

definitions: visible burning gas from fire producing light and heat
intense passion or strong romantic feeling
hostile or insulting message sent electronically
examples: Flames leaped from the burning building
The candle flame flickered in the breeze
Their old flame rekindled after twenty years apart
She still carried a flame for her first love
He sent flames to everyone who disagreed with him online
The forum moderator deleted the inflammatory flames

definitions: passionate Spanish art form combining singing, guitar playing, dance, and handclaps
examples: The flamenco performance captivated the audience with its intensity
She studied flamenco in Seville for three years
Traditional flamenco originated in Andalusia centuries ago
The guitarist played haunting flamenco melodies

definitions: mechanical device that projects long stream of fire
examples: Soldiers used flamethrowers to clear enemy bunkers
The flamethrower shot flames thirty feet forward
Agricultural flamethrowers help control weeds organically
The movie villain wielded a terrifying flamethrower

definitions: large pink or reddish wading bird with long legs and curved bill
examples: Flamingos stood on one leg in the shallow lagoon
The zoo's flamingo exhibit attracts many visitors
Wild flamingos get their pink color from their diet
A flock of flamingos created a stunning pink landscape

definitions: degree to which material or substance can be easily ignited and burn
examples: The fabric's flammability made it unsuitable for children's clothing
Engineers test materials for flammability before approval
High flammability of the chemicals required special storage
Building codes consider the flammability of construction materials

definitions: projecting rim or edge on object for strengthening, guiding, or attachment
examples: The pipe flange connects to the matching flange with bolts
Engineers specified a larger flange for added strength
The wheel flange keeps the train on its rails
Tighten the flange bolts to prevent leaks

definitions: side of person or animal between ribs and hip
right or left side of military formation or position
cut of meat from side of animal between ribs and leg
examples: The horse's flank glistened with sweat after the race
Pain in his left flank sent him to the doctor
Enemy forces attacked their exposed flank
Generals protected their flanks during battle
She ordered flank steak for the barbecue
Marinate the flank overnight for best flavor

definitions: rugby player positioned on side of scrum
soldier positioned on flank of military formation
examples: The flanker broke from the scrum to tackle the opposing player
Open-side flankers need exceptional speed and stamina
Flankers protected the main force from side attacks
The general positioned flankers along the ridge

definitions: soft woven fabric with loose texture typically made from wool or cotton
small cloth for washing face or body
meaningless or evasive talk intended to flatter or deceive
examples: He wore flannel pajamas during cold winter nights
The flannel sheets felt cozy against her skin
She used a flannel to remove her makeup
Keep a clean flannel by the bathroom sink
Stop the flannel and tell me the truth
His speech was pure flannel with no substance

definitions: piece attached on one side that covers opening or hangs loose
up and down movement of wings or similar motion
state of agitation, excitement, or panic
examples: The tent flap blew open in the wind
She sealed the envelope flap with glue
The bird's rapid flap carried it skyward
You could hear the flap of wings overhead
Don't get in a flap about the delayed flight
The missing documents caused quite a flap at headquarters

definitions: fashionable young woman in 1920s who challenged conventional behavior
hinged or flexible part that opens and closes valve or opening
examples: Flappers shocked society with their short skirts and bobbed hair
The museum exhibit featured flapper fashion from the Jazz Age
Replace the toilet flapper if water keeps running
The valve flapper controls water flow

definitions: repeated up and down movement of wings or similar parts
loose, uncontrolled movement of fabric or material
examples: The constant flapping of wings filled the aviary
Hummingbird flapping occurs at incredible speeds
The flapping of sails warned of the approaching storm
Secure the tarp to stop its annoying flapping

definitions: bright light or flame used as signal or warning
sudden burst or outbreak of activity, emotion, or symptoms
gradual widening of shape, especially in clothing
examples: The stranded sailor fired a flare into the night sky
Emergency flares lined the accident scene
A flare of anger crossed his usually calm face
Her arthritis flare lasted several painful days
Bell-bottom jeans have a dramatic flare at the ankle
The trumpet's flare amplifies its sound

definitions: sudden brief burst of bright light or flame
very brief moment or instant of time
brief news announcement about important event
examples: Lightning created a brilliant flash across the sky
The camera flash momentarily blinded everyone
The answer came to her in a flash of insight
The race ended in a flash with a photo finish
We interrupt this program with a news flash
The flash reported breaking news from the courthouse

definitions: scene in story showing events that happened earlier
sudden vivid memory of past event, often traumatic
examples: The movie used flashbacks to reveal the character's childhood
Multiple flashbacks explained the mystery's solution
War veterans often experience flashbacks of combat
The smell triggered a flashback to her grandmother's kitchen

definitions: thin waterproof material preventing water penetration at roof joints
light that repeatedly turns on and off
examples: The roofer installed flashing around the chimney
Damaged flashing caused the roof leak
The flashing lights warned drivers of construction ahead
Emergency vehicles use flashing blue lights

definitions: portable battery-powered electric light held in hand
examples: She grabbed a flashlight when the power went out
Keep a flashlight in your car for emergencies
The camping flashlight lasted all night on one charge
He searched under the bed with his flashlight

definitions: lowest temperature at which vapor ignites when exposed to flame
place or situation where violence or conflict is likely to develop
examples: Gasoline has a flashpoint of negative forty-five degrees Fahrenheit
Store chemicals below their flashpoint temperature
The disputed border remains a flashpoint for conflict
Rising unemployment created flashpoints throughout the region

definitions: bottle or container for holding liquids
small flat container for carrying alcohol in pocket
glass vessel used in laboratory for heating or mixing
examples: She carried water in a metal flask during hikes
The thermos flask kept coffee hot all day
He pulled a silver flask from his coat pocket
The hip flask held enough whiskey for several drinks
The scientist heated chemicals in a round-bottom flask
Laboratory flasks must be properly cleaned after use

definitions: self-contained housing unit occupying part of building
level surface or area without slopes or curves
tire that has lost air pressure
musical note lowered by half step
examples: They rented a two-bedroom flat in London
Her flat overlooks the Thames River
The flat prairie stretched for miles
Place the picture on a flat surface
We got a flat on the highway
The spare replaced the flat tire
He played B flat instead of B natural
The singer went flat on the high notes

definitions: truck or trailer with flat platform body without sides
scanner with flat glass surface for placing documents
examples: The flatbed truck carried construction materials
They loaded lumber onto the flatbed trailer
The flatbed scanner produces high-quality document copies
Place the photo face-down on the flatbed surface

definitions: bread made with flour and water without yeast, rolled flat before baking
examples: Mediterranean flatbread pairs perfectly with hummus
She baked whole wheat flatbread for dinner
Indian naan is a popular type of flatbread
The restaurant serves flatbread pizza as appetizers
